244 Lenox Ave
New York, N.Y. Nov. 15, 1888
My Dear Aunt Anna-
Your letter of Friday, and finished later came to me today.- this evening, as have one or two others since I have written. I have neglected you, but not forgotten you by any meas. I have had a good many yearnings t write to your but have been hindered from one or two reasons. I have been extremely busy; and besides, for a good many days, I have been without papers, and without money to buy any; but on this letter financial unclear - I have been fortunately relieved. Hopkins had no paper either or very little, so we were in something of a strait. You will pardon the color of this sheet,- it is all I happen to have around me at this present moment though. I might give you a better sheet- if I should take the time to go out after it.
Did I tell you that Mrs. Jones told me the first time I called on here, the morning of my arrival, that would give me a hundred

very snowy winter this year. I will try and write Maggie and J Butler soon
Affectionately
Your

As soon as she learned of my intention of studying for the ministry, she offered it in her decisive, matter of fact way, as though it were a matter of business, or a matter for which she took in credit to herself. Olpe, Kans. Dec. 29 1888
Dear Aunt Anna,
Your letter is before me dated Nov. 19 and I am sorry I have not answered it before. I have been very busy with my studies and have not found much time to write.
I came home a week ago yesterday and College begins again Jan. 7 which gives me two weeks to rest. Ever since I came home I have had a cold and have had to stay in-doors most of the time. We have had very little winter so far.
There is now snow enough on the ground for very fair sleighing. Chas. has been skating several times on the creek.

I like College very much and we four have considerable fun together. You ask which of us is the best cook. It is hard to tell but they all are better than I am. I think that essay that you referred to is destroyed. We have meetings of the society every Friday evening at the College and I have debated once and am on the program for two weeks form last night for a declamation.
I have the following studies: - Greek, Latin, English, Algebra, Biblical, and Drawing.
I have Greek and Latin each five times a week Algebra 4 times English twice and Biblical and Drawing each once a week.
I do not come home very often and when I do I always go back on Saturday and so do not get to

attend church here.
I have taken my letter from Elmendaro (where Papa & Mama are members) and handed it in at the Arundel Ave. Presby Church of Emporia Kansas.
I received a letter from John Eddie about the first of Dec. which I will try and answer as soon as possible.
I do not hear from Dwight or Irving now at all. Dwight owes me a letter and I don't know wether he intends to write or not. I hear from some of the Turin quite often.
You will please excuse poor letter writing as I have not the best place to write. I will be obliged to draw my letter to a close, with love to all and a Merry Xmas & Happy New Year. I remain yours truly
J.E. Everett

244 Lenox Ave
New York March 23, 1889.
My Dear Aunt Anna: -
I was so sorry to hear that you have not been so well lately that I wanted to go right home to see you.
I have been meaning to write all the week. but have been quite busy with one thing and another. I have not had time to write now as the breakfast bell will ring in a very few minutes. I hope you are much better by his time.
I called on Mrs. Twombly one evening last week. I had not called before since early in the fall. I had a very pleasant evening, for I guess I stayed till nearly ten o clock. Miss Alive and her mother were there. They are going to break up housekeeping in a little over a month. I will see about Aunt Mary's things. Some of them I can make good use of at the Seminary. - Well, the bell

has just rung and I will close. My health has been pretty good.
A week ago Sunday I preached at Bellmore, Long Island, about 26 miles out. I am still looking around for something for the summer, but have nothing definitely in view yet.
I hope this may get to you tonight
Affectionately
J.E.E.

244 Lenox Ave. New York
Apr. 2, 1889
My Dear Aunt Anna: -
It looks very much I am sure as thought I had forgotten you, but I have not. I do not think of any real good excuse for not writing this long time; but I have been busy some times and perhaps negligent oftener __ The latter is the more truthful excuse, I guess. For I have not been working so hard lately as I did the first of the year. I have not been pushed quite so hard with work. 
Our examinations at the Seminary begin in a month, a month from yesterday and last four days. The school will go on anther month. - I will not be here another year. I have informed the Perrius? to the effect, or rather Hopkins did; for he was speaking about himself, and spoke about me at the same time. He will not stay either. - I shall be able to get along I am sure. next year. If I have to teach, it will be better

for me to tutor a little;, but I do not think I shall need to.
I said I went to Belmore, Long Island to preach one Sunday. I only got my expenses. One of the Seniors has had the place for more than a year, but does not always go out himself. He leaves anyway this Spring and he sent out a number of fellows at different times, so that the people might pick out one for the summer. I heard that he was going to leave a place which would need a man for the summer and I spoke to him; - that is how I went there. The choice finally lay between myself and another man, and the other man got the majority of votes. - The pay there would have been about nine dollars a week and board. This other man, is not going there however:  the Board had recommended a man, who will be permanent, which of course will be much better for them.
I have made advances, too, with a view to securing another place. A chapel which is connected with the Church whose S.S. I am with

now, employs a man in the Summer, to do Sunday School work, a part of the season, and to preach for two months or so while the regular pastor is having a vacation. The man who was there last Summer, has been working in that S. S. this year, as indeed he did last year too. He is going West this summer to do Mission work in Texas. He has promised to suggest my name if he has an opportunity. He presumes he will be asked to suggest some name, as they will expect to secure a Seminary man. There is a vacation of three weeks, I believe with the place. The compensation is $200, for the Summer. That is not so much as it seems, as board & room will eat up about a half of it. - I am not at all sure of getting the place to be sure, but if it fails me, I think there will be other opportunities. It seems to me that I out to try to get something to do this summer. 
You ask about my health. It has been good. Perhaps I spoke as I did in my letter, because I was sick one day a month or six weeks ago. It was on my birthday. My bowels troubled.

me for a day or two, and on that day I was real sick, and had to keep my bed all morning. A week ago and for a few days previous I had a very severe cold, but I have recovered and am all right now. 
I send five dollars to reimburse you in part for what you paid to Smith in selling that book-bill?. I happen to have so much that I do not need just now. I hope to send you the rest of it before the summer comes. I ordered a pair of pantaloons the other day, I expect to get them tonight or tomorrow. I am to pay seven dollars for them. Give my kindest regards to Miss Huddleston.
Yours Affectionately
"J. Eddie"

Osawatomie
Sept 20, 1890
Dear Anna,
John Eddie left us yesterday after supper. The boys took him down, and he had also for company, 'Lonzo, Carl and Johnny Reynolds, a merry brood six in all! There was a show in town, a man exhibiting Wizard oil, and Herman and Will and the rest went. [Crossed out: went there, Carl and Johnny went to see some wizard oil works] Their father and another were there too. J. Eddie expected to start about midnight and reach Anthony about 10 am today. The boys left him at the depot. It was a pretty cool night - and I wanted him to take a shawl to throw on him the night- as he did and intend taking a sleeper, but thought his overcoat would be all sufficient - Many agreed with him. It was a lovely clear night with good sized moon and today is

I think it is better for Dooters to do so. I could hold one for him until he is through at least but it may be best to make some other arrangement after a little. I do not feel willing to haul...[illegible]]

is what you might call an ideal day.  We have a heavy force of workmen, Mr. Reynolds, Pearl & Johnny in the cornfield, Will and German? carrying hay.  If Eddie has started Thursday instead of Friday it would have been a sorry ride for him to town for there was one of those pouring rains which we have had this fall-something like that Mary and John ? one evening coming to town. J.E. had just got in on his return from the p. o. when the storm burst.   He was alone on horseback and we were beginning to be uneasy about him. We were just ready to sit down to table and the boys both went to take his horse and get through before the rain.  John was in the milk room skimming and straining-he was a pretty wet man when he hurried in after finishing.  He put the milk pails out in the yard just as they were and in the morning when I

washed them I was surprised to find how much water they had caught-when I got into bed I landed in a small ? of water.  We got up lit the lamp, pulled the bed out and Mary changed places with me because I coughed and she was fearful I might get wet.  We had not noticed the water dropping on the bed.  We did not get any more of it and slept nicely. -Yesterday ?. I went over to Mrs. R's for a bouquet for J. Eddie-she had invited me to do so the day before when she drove into the yard.  It was very pretty and he carried it in his trunk-I cannot begin to tell you the many varieties it contained-zinnia, dalia, lighted cigar? geraniums [[?].   The coxcomb and everlasting I kept to dry and send by and by with his clothes that Mary & I failed to put in order for him. -Mary worked hard putting on fresh buttons on his coat and vest ? just as he started.   I

put up his ?-not a very large one and a quaker brand of oat meal box.  Mary wants to know if you have ? of coal ((underlined)) and if you flannels. ((underlined))  You see she ((underlined)) thinks of you while ramble on about things here! ((underlined))  I must close as they are just ready to go.  Much love for all-  J. E.
P.S. So cousin Jennie with you yet.  It must be most ? times.  Is ? with James?  How is she?  Has Clara? changed much.  Did you see Maggie when she was home last?  Is she looking well?  How was cousin Alex when you heard last?  I will try to write to them soon-

Harper, Kansas, November 29, 1890.
My Dear Aunt Anna:----

        I heard from you yesterday and a day or two before that as well.  I am glad to hear from you so often.  I am sure you are nicely situated there.   I remember the room well.  Give my kindest regards to Cousin Lucy and all the family.
   I took Thanksgiving dinner with Mrs. Patterson, at Anthony.  She is one of our members.  She is about as much at home in Harper as in Anthony.  She is the wife of the brother of my Hotel proprietor? of Harper.  Her husband is really a Harper man, but they are living in Anthony now as he is the County Clerk, and Anthony is the County Seat.  He was away on business, but there were other company.
    We had a delightful Thanksgiving day, as far as the weather went.  It was warm and balmy.  With an overcoat it was just nice sitting out doors.  And if it would not have been ?, crossed out uncomfortable without one even,----   We had a nice service, good music , good audience?, flowers +c.  I did not try to preach a profound national sermon, but a practical sermon on

gratitude.

   There is a convention in Anthony ?, crossed out held in the interest of the Y.M.C.A. today + tomorrow.  I will be there most of today, but cannot be there tomorrow as I exchange with another man and go to Crisfied.

                                                                  must close
                                                                  Affectionately
                                                                  Eddie

Anthony, Kansas
May 18,1891.
My Dear Aunt Aura?! -
I received another letter from you yesterday, on my return to Harper. I am glad you are giving the matter of coming West "serious consideration".
The possible Event which you suggest of Aunt Mary having to go East, I had not considered in its relation to your coming West, when I wrote, though I thought of it afterwards. And of course I have nothing say in regard to your wishing to be East then. That is a matter we cannot tell anything about.
The end might be hastened. The clouds have gathered heavily about her, and they can be cleared away only when she awakes? in the clear radience of a new day. 
Give my love to Aunt Jan and Clara. I suppose unclear is still with them. 
Remember me to him too. 
Yours Affectionately
J. unclear

in the near future, it seems right and proper for us to consider it in making our plans.

       In regard to your coming first alone, I have nothing to say either.  Would you feel that you could attempt the journey without Company?

      Has Aunt Mary written you that I paid them a visit last week.  I did not have much of an idea how badly off Aunt Jennie was until last Monday, (a week ago today) when I got a letter stating her condition much more fully that any before. Realizing suddenly how low she is I determined to go up there for a day.  I felt I could do no good, but being here in the state I thought it right for me to go see her again. (You ask the distance.  It is 220 on

230 miles.  The distance from New York to Ithica is 247.)   So I went Monday afternoon starting a 2.45 and reaching Osawatonie a little after day light Tuesday morning.  I got breakfast in town, and then walked over to the farm.  I started back, that night, reaching here 10.10 Wednesday Morning.

         Aunt Jennie knew me, and seemed perhaps glad to see me, tho' after the first she, crossed out greeting she seemed not to consider that I had not been there all the time.  She did not mention it, crossed out anything which indicated that she thought I had been away anywhere, indeed she did not say very much except to call for something, Which she did very often when awake, and almost incessantly some of the time.  She seems to

be in a good deal of distress when awake, tho' she is so delerious and irrational that it is hard to tell whether she has much really conscious suffering-  When I came to bid her good bye she simply said "Are you going way off again?" ((underlined)) and she pressed my hand, thus showing that she had some appreciation of my visit.  But I stayed in the room sometime after that, and she did not say anything more, nor speak to me again.

    She seems to have a good deal of vitality yet, and unless a change comes I should not expect her to drop away just yet.  But I suppose such a change is likely to come anytime. Merrill, Mich
Oct. 29, 1894.
My Dear Aunt Anna:-
I was sorry to hear that Aunt Mary was worse Thursday. We hope it was but temporary, and that she has been better since then. It seems to take a long time to get word back and forth between there and here; so that after last Thursday there has been time for great changes. We hope there has been a great change and for the better.
Ella is pretty nearly sick. She has felt poorly since Saturday. She is around, but is far from well. She has some feelings like the grip. with great nervousness.

I am not sure that she has been quite so well since the night of the surprise. We appreciate that event very much. We feel that our friends were very kind. The silverware is very nice, and the chair too. - Baby went to church yesterday, and behaved himself very well, for him. The weather is beautiful here now, I am going to take Ella for a ride this morning to see if it will not do her good in this nice autumn morning.
We hope to hear from you again today or tomorrow.
I think you ought to try to get a girl? if you can, so that you can get along as easily as possible.
With love from all
J.E. Everett.

Cannon Falls, Minn
May 28, 1927, Saturday morning
Dear Helen and Mary
I wonder how you are there at the hospital and at 311 3rd Street, Southwest this morning. It is still cloudy and there is appearance of more rain today.
Yesterday afternoon Prof. Sandberg, the piano turner, brought a fish around. I told Mrs. Valentine I would like to bestow it somewhere where there was an appetite for fish. She said Mr. V liked fish; so she said she would cook it for supper and I should come over. It was a good and tasty fish. That made two meals with the Valentines yesterday.
I understand that Marry Curran is home, I started over to call on the Cliffords yesterday afternoon, but changed my mind and did not go. I went to try to see Mrs. Alva Conley? about music for Sunday, as we are likely to have a good congregation, with

Ellis announced as the speaker. She was in the Cities so I did not see her, I called her up in the evening, and she said she would try to have a choir; but Mrs. Scriver will be away and Mrs. S.L.C. has company - so Mrs. Grace said. But perhaps the matter will take shape better than I anticipate, surely Mrs. S.L.C. will do her part.
I painted the hall floor and every other step of the stairs last night. I believe I will not paint the other steps till Monday; but I can tell better what the best way will be by tonight.
The tea man came yesterday when I was out. I will probably see him today.
Marguerite Swedenberg, Helen, said she had a similar operation to yours, with a local anesthetic.
Mary, how are you feeling? This week adds a new twist to your experience. I hope I shall hear from you this morning, so I can hear how your mother is getting along. Are those Kansas folks still at the house? I guess it would have been better if we had moved & taken quarters nearer the hospital.
Love - Father.

Around Sparta, Wis.
Dear Helen:
We have been out of Lacrosse about 40 minutes. At that place the train stopped 10 minutes and I got out and got a lunch. I afterwards ate a banana. This is turning out a fine day. I see by a paper that there was a bad storm around Milwaukee last night about 6 and 7 o clock. 
Since leaving Wabasha I have had a seat all to myself. But, the coach seems to be filling and I probably will not have this good luck long.

I think you are not troubled today with the house being chilly.
I had a pleasant drive with Mr. Englebart this morning. He took me first to the depot that I might make sure of the time of the train leaving. Then we drove uptown, as I wanted to get toothpaste, also collar. Then he drove me pack to the depot. My fare was $8.62. The regular fare is $12.93 or something like that.
The train time was 9:30, fifteen minutes later than my old time table said, but we got there at about 8:30.

I am glad I have the young people's meeting provided for, though I realize that Alonzo may not agree to my plan.
I hope you will get long well when I am away and be able not to be too busy. I will write you two or three times more.
With love
J.E.

Mrs. Helen Everett
Cannon Falls
Minnesota

Mrs. J.E. Everett
Cannon Falls
Minn.

April 10, 1929
Wednesday
Dear Helen,
It is now about 10 o'clock in the morning, and we are in the room. After breakfasting, Roberts had an interview with a man, and has been phoning in order to make some appointments for the day and now has his day - or the rest of it pretty fully mapped out with either places he is going or men who are under appointment to meet him here.
I am going out with him when he gets these matters arranged.
By the way, it will be better for you not to talk about the Atlantic City matter as it may have to be postponed for a year, on account of lack of time this year
With love
J.E.

Clinton, N.Y. Sept. 18, 1884.
Dear Aunt Jennie:
I failed to get around to the bank this afternoon before four o'clock, and so did not deliver that note or make any inquiries in regard to the matter. I will send the note, however, by the mail which takes this together with an explanation or statement of the fact that I failed to call on them yesterday. I hope you have found the book by this time. I did not go to Cousin Mary's. Has Frankie had her Autograph Album yet? I will write again longer, soon, if I can find anything to say. 
With Love all around
Your Nephew
J.E. Everett.

Clinton, N.Y. Sept 19, 1884
Dear Aunt Jennie
The enclosed letter from the Bank I received this evening. I presume you have heard from there as well.
All is passing off pleasantly. I think it will not be hard to catch up in my lessons; that is as far as the outside work is concerned; the recitations that I missed are a loss I suppose.
I have not delivered the packages to the young lady at Florence Sem. yet but intend to do so, tomorrow afternoon Wednesday and Saturday afternoons we have no recitations. There was a weding in town

last evening. The daughter of Prof. Theodore Dwight Prof. Dwight's home is in Clinton but he is the Law proffesor in Columbia College. They are related to Mr Avery.
Yours Nephew With Love
J.E. Everett.

As I said before give my love to Clair and all the rest. Uncle Butler and Lizzie and Claire (that makes three times for [Claire?]) and Anna and Holden and Hattie. You see I have named them by families in the order of their establishment Of what class  is Holden a member? If he is a Sophomore do not mention it for from principle am opposed to sophamores.
Clinton, NY, Mar. 16, 1885
My dear Aunt Jennie; Yours of the 14th is at hand. I am sorry that I have kept you so long without word from me. Please excuse my pencil. I am not on the hill but at my boarding house. In about an hour, or such a matter, I am going to call at Mr. Avery's and will learn what I can about the Dwight family - they are related to Mr. Avery you know. However I am able to say that Prof Dwight does not have a school here now.You ask for college news or even gossip you say. I do not think of any news in particular just this

In sending my love to Claire and the rest of them do not think I have forgotten to allot a due  + double portion to you, affectionate J Eddie
minute; and as for gossip I am afraid it would not be much interest to you. I am sure you cannot be interested in knowing that Ayers and Ellenwood "flunked" in "Math" today, or that Prof Frink caught a man "cribbing this morning, or that Tom Millar threw a rubber at the Presidents head the other morning or that Kessinger has several times lounged in his room during recitation and sent Jones to tell the Professor that he has had a telegraph dispatch suddenly calling him to Rome. These things of course may very easily furnish themes for conversation for us, but you know to appreciate gossip you must know something of the parties talked about. Last evening the communion

service was held in the College Church. One man united with the church by profession of faith and three I believe by letter  - students of course, all of them. I have decided to try and write a prize essay. The subject was given out last term you remember - two subjects in fact, to choose from. The Historical Associations of New Orleans, and Earthquakes. I have chosen Earthquakes. I ought to have begun to read up on it long ago, but I had rather made up my mind that I had not time. But I have finally decided to take what time I can and do the best I can under the circumstances. I cannot possibly take the prize, as there are men who have been reading

and thinking on the subject for a long time. I have only a little over two weeks before it must be handed in. It is to contain not over 3500 words. I am writing it, not for the prize, but for my own sake. I would always regret it I am afraid if I did not try; because I have had time enough all this term if I had only economized it. I find that when I have a good deal of work to do, I can do a good deal; not always satisfactorily, but I am quite as apt to do it satisfactorily as when I have plenty of time + am not pushed. Give my love to Claire and all the rest. I guess I'll write a little

more while I'm about it. - I have three recitations a day except Wednesday and Saturday and on those days we are obliged to attend Rhetorical exercises in the chapel which takes more time or at least as much, as a recitation but requires no preparation of course, except when it is one's turn to take part. For Thursday we have only two recitations to prepare for; one recitation that day is Essay reading. We are having now Odessey (is it spelled right? I am much more familiar with it in the original tongue) four times a week; Greek Testiment, one hour, Mathematics four hours

Mandeville's Reading and Oratory six hours. Mandeville comes only the last three or four weeks of the term; before that we had Livy six hours. The scheme is to give Livy four hours + Mandeville two hours. The common Hamilton College substitution for the word Mandeville may be ascertained by striking out the e from the middle and the le from the end of the word. I may state however, that there is, at least, one exception to the general rule that all the students make this substitution. There is slang enough on the hill to fill a dictionary; and one thinks at first that he needs a dictionary to learn the meaning of it all. But he soon "gets on to it" - "you bet," and is able to "sling it off for business."

Anthony, Kansas
November 11, 1890
My dear Aunt Jennie
I was thinking it was about time to get another Osawatomie letter when I received yours today which seems to be dated Nov 4. - though perhaps it is the 9th. 
I will be glad to go with Father to Kansas City, anytime he may think he is ready to go. - at least , so far as I can tell now. I write this again because it has just occurred to me that I said in my letter mailed this morning that I feared I would not be able to visit Osawatomie until after Christmas. But when he wants to go to Kansas City I want to go with him.
I had a nice ride into the country seven miles today and called on their families. I borrowed a horse and cart of Mr. Wilson. I think I shall defer

getting a horse indefinitely. I believe it will be cheaper to hire a horse when I want one than to keep one. Feed is so high, that it would cost a good deal I am afraid. I can write you in a couple of days how I get along at the wedding. The third wedding that I spoke of which might fall to me, will probably go to someone else, as I learned today that the young lady is a member of another church, though her father belongs to our church.
Affectionately,
John Edward Everett

Harper, Kansas
November 17, 1890
My dear Aunt Jennie,
On my return to Harper Saturday, I found your letter or Aunt Mary's with Robbie's letters which you copied. Thank you for copying them. They interested me more than I can tell you. I am sorry Robbie is so hard pressed. But better times will dawn for him, I am sure, because he is an honest man with industrious habits and keenness and knowledge of general affairs sufficient to make him a good competitor in the worlds great strife.
I want you to pay me a visit after while, when I get ahead a little in my financial matters. I have a pleasant boarding place at Anthony and I think you would enjoy it. It would be pleasant for me, and a nice change and rest for you.
Last night I preached on

the hearts and needs of young men. I preached the same sermon at Anthony the previous week, and I think the people were generally pleased at both places. I propose to preach to young people, sometimes, once a month or so.
As ever
Affectionately,
John Edward Everett

Sedan. Kansas
July 28, 1890
My Dear Aunt Mary!
I lose track sometimes of my correspondence. I am not sure whether I wrote to you last Week or not. I believe not, however; so I will make sure of writng this week early. I guess I wrote to Aunt Anna last week.
I preached at UK City yesterday morning, and returned here for the evening. UK City is in the County East of here. (Montgomery.) I am invited to be present at the dedication of a church not many miles from Sedan (Caney)

next Sunday. I am not sure, that I shall go because, I dislike to leave my work here the Sundays in successions However, if the people think I ought to go I shall go of course. I should like to be there : it would be very pleasant. But I should have to be away all day.
In regard to your precautions or rather suggestions about my calling about my church peoples I will say that I do call on them all, and sometimes, too; on a few of "a few of" superscribed the families of the other churches. Even the family who lives out of town I try to go and see once in two weeks at least sometimes oftener.
I do not know where your last letter is, and cannot remember whether

There are many questions to be answered or not. I suppose there were queries as to my health. I have been well all summer- every day. Have not had a cold nor an ache nor a pain. I confess I was pretty lazy when the weather was hot, but it affected me no more seriously than to make me uncomfortable, and to make my wash bill a little higher. But I had never seen anything like it before. The thermometer was up of a hundred and over [underlined: almost every day] for more than a month. I suppose it was the same with you. But last week it was quite comfortable.
I am sorry to learn that Will Shaefer is not well. I hope he will soon be all right.
We have moved from the Mansion

house. Mr. Bryan rented the building, and the owner wanted to move in and keep the hotel. So Mr. Bryan has taken another house. His boarders have followed him, however.
The room I have now is larger than the one I had at the Mansion House. But it has no south window. At the Mansion House when I went there, I chose a North West Corner room, because I thought it would be cooler in the morning when I wanted to be in my room mostly. Mrs. B. Told me I would do better to take the South East room which was vacant too. But I thought I knew my business. She said I could change anytime while the other room was vacant. After a few weeks, I found that I had made a mistake, and changed.  I got into a room then with South and East windows and the difference was more then perceptible, as you may

well imagine.

My Dear Aunt Mary:--
Your letter of last Saturday and Sunday came to us this morning (Wednesday.)  I suppose it was mailed Monday morning. Yes we are pretty near together, notwithstanding the 1400 miles or thereabouts separating us. If I remember correctly, my brother Robbie started from Utica, when he came west, at six oclock Monday night, and reached Paola the following Friday evening or afternoon. That was in 1869, thirty-five years ago, and in March, too, if I am not mistaken. I believe it was in March in '55 that Father + family reached Kansas.
Thank you for your words of encouragement. I do not think that I have been particularly discouraged this winter though our affairs have been a good deal tangled,--or at least have been unsettled, so that we have seemed to be held in mid-air. We have an assurance that all things will work together and are working together for our good--and that Providence is working in our lives. I cannot believe it to be otherwise.
I wrote you in my last that I am now asked to return to the secretaryship of the Union. Of course we feel very grateful that the committee with whom I have worked for two years are inclined to show their confidence in me in this manner; but I think it quite doubtful whether I shall accept the

work again.
We are having another event at our house that slightly disturbs the even tenor of our way. Howard has the scarlet fever, and I am quarantined out and the rest of the family in. I have a room in the same block, across the street. We were quarantined yesterday. We are hoping none of the rest will take the disease. Howard had it before when he was small.
I have written to Uncle Eddie since received your letter reminding me that I ought to do so.
I am glad you are taking good care of yourself. It is very essential that you do so. Your springtime? may be in prospect already, but it is not very near after all. You will doubtless have some time yet in which to be very careful.
Helen tells me to say to you that the blue yarn was used to overstitch (if that is the proper word) a little jacket for Edward, cut out of an old-fashioned knit scarf or muffler.
Helen read your letter to me through the window. This is one of the new experiences that we meet from time to time,--one of life's vicissitudes that we pray continuously for strength to endure. But so far as I am concerned, I am not having it very hard. Those that are shut in are the real suffers.
Hope to continue to hear from you often. Give my love please to Aunt Jane. Am sorry indeed that she has had a relapse, but trust she will soon be strong again. With love also to May + much to yourself--Your Nephew--J.E. Everett

My Dear Aunt Mary: -
Yours written after returning from the Island was received yesterday noon. I was thinking before receiving it that it was about time for me to write you again.
Roberts has gained 6 1/2 pounds since he took his new start six weeks ago. He continues quite well. His school will begin two weeks from next Monday. Margaret has a very interesting anticipation of the opening of school, as she is expecting to begin her career then. Another little six year old, Za Adams, is also to begin school at the same time, and the two are hoping to sit together.
The Ladies Society meets at the parsonage today and their task today is to do some sewing for Helen. The society sews for people at so much per sitting, - only 50¢ I believe when they sew for one of their own number. Helen has been quite busy the last few days getting things for this onslaught. We will borrow two or three extra sewing machines, and if all is well, may

expect some large execution to better result. The president of the society is a vigorous worker of 80 years in age. She is wise and tactful as well as energetic and she keeps things moving both briskly and smoothly. Sometimes 20 or 30 ladies gather in these meetings for work, and I believe usually as many as fifteen or twenty. They meet once in two weeks.
I am sure you had a good visit at Holland Patent the other day. I wish I could have been there, too. Is Frances well? Does she enjoy her work? When I saw her three years ago, she spoke of taking a medical course sometime, Does she still contemplate doing so?
Is Clara enjoying her vacation, now nearly over with? I wish I could drop into Oneida County without ceremony, and have a little visit there. I hope Aunt Jane is well.
Next Sunday I am hoping to drive the family to Western Park. We have open air services there that day in a grove a mile from the church, and people are going to bring their lunches and stay all day. We fed them sandwiches & cake on the little wooden butter plates or shells from the grocer store. & gave them lemonade, all they could drink. and I guess some of them never drank so much lemonade at one time before.

My Dear Aunt Mary:--
It is such a long time since I have written to you that I am indeed ashamed of myself. But I have thought of you every day nevertheless. I have seemed to have a good deal to break up my time lately, and yet I have not been unusually busy, nor have I accomplished very much. We all keep along in about the same old way. Last week I attended a Christian Endeavor Convention at Eureka, spending a day and a half, and having a profitable and pleasant time.
Roberts has a small herd of six town cows to take out to the pasture mornings and bring back nights. He takes them from a half a mile to a mile from town. He has

done his work afoot till within a day or two when he has used our horse. The horse is big and strong, and sometimes a little headstrong, too, so that, on the whole gentle, I have been a little afraid to have Roberts use--crossed out ride him. But I think that gradually he will get so that he can use him safely.
Margaret was considerably indisposed a few days ago, but it lasted only two or three days. She thought it was brought on by eating mulberries. Roberts is taking lessons on the organ this summer. He is not particularly fond of music, but is making pretty good progress with his lessons.
We have had quite a good gardens, with lettuce, onions, radish, beans, peas and beets, and we have tomatoes, cabbage and parsnips in prospect. We have tomatoes as large as eggs one our vines, and the cabbage are beginning to head. We also have

(3)
cucumbers formed on the vines, but they are not large enough to use. I mean to set out a few to--crossed out strawberry vines--crossed out plants this summer.
Zaidee is now at home. She is reading Virgil. I have another girl reading it with her, one of her last winter's room mates. I have a pupil in Cicero too. Zaidee does not have much time for study as she has to help so much with the housework.
Howard has work in Topeka. I believe I wrote you that he was expecting work with Mr. Coburn, Sec'y. of the State Board of Agriculture where twenty or thirty extra clerks are now engaged compiling the state census, which is taken once in ten years,--the years ending with "5." We presume the work will last all summer though we are not sure. He gets nine dollars a week, and

where he boards he does some chores to partly pay his board, and room, which thus costs him in cash only two dollars a week.
Little Mary grows and gets sweeter all the time. Edward is round like a log, and enjoys being out of doors this weather. As to the baby's middle name, I think it will be Anna.
Tomorrow is my Western Park day. I enjoy going out there, but I find it a pretty wearisome work. We have a good horse, which is a help.
I will close now, hoping that you will find it convenient to write very soon.

Our lives are uneventful here, and so I have not much, seemingly, to write about. Another minister visited his parents here, a student at Northwestern, preached for me at Severy, two weeks ago.

Last week I attended a County Sunday School Convention at Eureka staying over night, and having a good visit with Zaidee. Tomorrow we plan to go, some or all of us to one of our Western Park families to spend apart of or all of the day. This is a young married couple, very devoted to the church, he being the superintendent of our Park S.S. Milo Mansinger. They live about half way between the Park church and here,--about six miles out. I am planning to be in Emporia Oct 24-26, to attend our Southern Congregational Association.
I haven't heard from Hattie for some time and therefore do not know whether they are permanently located again or not. Have you heard? One of our Kansas Cong. ministers, Dr. Frank G. Ward of Emporia, has, I notice, been recently called to Lansing, Michigan but I have not learned whether he has accepted.
Our least one: your namesake, is a bright, attractive little tot. She has pretty light chestnut colored hair that glistens in the sunlight. We think it will likely grow quite dark. Her eyes are large and pretty,

a very dark blue, which we suppose will turn black or brown perhaps. Her hair seems different at different times--sometimes quite light, sometimes a decided chestnut, sometimes almost read. When not cross, she is a splendid little thing. She creeps lithely, and walks about around chairs, and we hope she will take to walking in good earnest before long. Helen and I have sometimes remarked that she is the only one of our four who has not a spoon from the aunties to keep and to be a memento. Roberts and Margaret has each one from you and Aunt Anna, and Edward one from you. Edward's is the only one that has been used. He used his a great deal, but has lately discarded it partly, so that his mother has put it away with the rest.
Well. I will close now, hoping to write again before long, and hoping also that we may hear from you again too quite soon.

J.E. Everett

Severy, Kan. Dec. 4, 1905,
My Dear Aunt Mary:--
It is so long since I have written to you that I hardly know where to begin. But I can do no better than to begin by acknowledging the very pretty and sweet and delicate spoon that came for Mary today, which I am sure you sent. We are greatly pleased with it. It is certainly a very fine Christmas present for the little lady, or birthday present perhaps. She herself seemed to understand that the present was for her. She is walking now, and has been for some time. She has been weaned for, I think, about four weeks, and is quite well. She has a voracious appetite. She is getting more chubby cheeked than she has ever been. Edward, too, is fat and healthy, though he takes cold easily.
Zaidee came home Wednesday last

for Thanksgiving, and goes back tomorrow. We had public Thanksgiving service in our church, at which I preached. Usually Severy has a public--crossed out union Thanksgiving service, but a peculiar failure to have such a service occurred this year,--so we had a meeting of our own.
In October, we had a helpful series of special meeting at Western Park for two weeks. In November we had a similar series, for the same length of time at Severy. Between the two periods I was in Emporia two or three day attending our Southern Congregational Association, so my time has been taken up pretty fully. I had a good visit at Uncle Eddie's in Emporia. They are all pretty well, or were at that time.
Roberts and Margaret are both making good progress in school, and they are both in quite good health. We have the same girl staying with us and going to school as we had last year. The principal of our school was sick a short time ago, and almost suffered a breakdown. I taught for him two days, and am still teaching his two Latin class, giving to the work an hour a day, and receiving fifty cents for the work.

Severy, Kansas, April 5, 1906.--
My Dear Aunt Mary,
I have been greatly rejoiced recently by getting such good long letters from you. I hope this good practice may continue. I do not have any hope of being able to write you a very long letter this time. But I want to write nevertheless.
I guess I have not written you since a brief attack of rheumatism which I had recently. I had felt it coming on for a good many days; and finally on March 23, I came down on my back,--with the painful disease in my back. However I was not kept down long. That was on Friday, and I was up again the next Tuesday. My sick Sunday was my Severy Sunday. The following Sunday, which was last Sunday

I did not go to the Park, though as it proved, I think I might easily have done so. Being here I held services here. I am well again, feeling only a little catch when I stoop over or make certain motions.
We learn that Zaidee is not in very good health, + has had to be out of college some, and to give up one of her studies, her German. Her eyes are also troubling her. We have thought seriously for a day or two of having her come home + give up her studies till next fall. You ask the address of Howard. It is 1100 Topeka Ave, Topeka, and Zaidee's address is 1927 Harrison Street.
Roberts and Margaret were much pleased to receive your letters to them today. No, Roberts was not near sighted before getting his glasses, but had grown to be far sighted. The first thing I noticed that did not seem right was that in reading he would hold his book or paper out at arm's length. The occulist thinks that he will quite likely outgrow the difficulty

(3)
In regard to the Sunday School books I confess the cost of an edition, as you quote Mrs. Griffith is much less than I thought it would be, and I cannot but wonder whether there may not be some mistake. But even at that price the profit will be doubtful when advertising (if you should continue to advertise) and postage is take into account. And quitely likely in the long run the profit would dwindle down to nothing. The trouble also is a considerable for you to attend to. I do not feel the--crossed out sure that it would be wise to get the edition out. But if you feel that you really ought to do so, I would certainly not want to discourage you. But we may very gratefully and proudly remember that we do not need to seek to continue the prestige + career of usefulness that the little book has had, for it has now been on the market far longer than most books continue to be used, and we can therefore well afford to let it pass int the realm of the historical.

I have an old copy here printed in 1848, and it says it is the second edition ( for "ail" is "second," is it not?) Supposing the first edition to have been printed two years earlier, we may ascribe to the work a living career of not less than 60 years. Not many books live as long as that.
Helen will possibly write a short letter to go in this. She wishes to do so. But she does not, apparently, have control of her time, with her household duties, + the demands of baby.

Fowler, Kansas, July 1, 1906
My Dear Aunt Mary:--
I will write you a few words this afternoon, as I have not written you for some little time. We have been in a "period of transition," and I have neglected my correspondence. I am not sure, indeed, that I acknowledged to you the receipt of the Utica box, and I am sure that I did not acknowledge it to the cousins. I will try to write them tomorrow. The things came just as we were tearing up and packing, so I put off writing about them till I should be more settled. We were very much pleased with them, and are indeed grateful to the cousins, and grateful to you for having them sent. Roberts is pretty well provided for now for--crossed out with coats and pants; and the waists for him fill a pressing need and help wonderfully. The largest coat I shall be able to wear some, and Mr. Davies, our Welsh friend at Severy, who is a tailor, lengthened the sleeves for me so as to make the garment usable. The

largest pantaloons, too, lengthened out, are suitable for me.
I am, for the time, at Ford and Fowler, I am at Fowler today and shall return to Ford about the 4th to remain there till about the 12th, when I shall come back here for about a week. I believe I wrote you that I might be addressed at Ford, so I may hear from you even before you receive this.
The family are at Topeka, at 1820 Clay Street. Strangely we are at--crossed out in the same block from which we moved two years ago, and in the house where we stayed and were hospitably entertained after tearing up, a house belonging to Mr. Huggins, and from which the Huggins family had moved a few days before we went back. I tried hard not to take that house, thinking I could get lower rent; but I failed to get anything suitable, excepting one other house, which was a little cheaper, but all things considered, I judged the one I took to be more

(3)
satisfactory.
I came up to Topeka on the 20th taking Margaret as far as Emporia, and leaving her there till the others should follow. That was on Wednesday. That evening Howard and I went house hunting. We found a house quite far out toward the city limits that we could have had for $10 a month if we had been an hour later,--a new house, and in a good neighborhood, and very suitable. But it had just been taken. The next day I continued the work alone, and did not fully decide till Friday morning, to take Mr. Huggins' house. The folks came Friday at one oclock, having gathered up Margaret on the way.
One of our old neighbors,--our, former next door neighbor--the Seeleys--invited us to supper that night, so we felt that we were back among our friends. We could not do much that day toward getting settled, as the drays were

slow in getting our things out to us. I had an appointment at Ford the next Sunday, and so I had to leave in the middle of that night. Howard has been able to help some, and a good, strong colored woman who used to wash for us would help as needed. This is not a very pleasing arrangement, but for the present I am glad to have it so. We have a double expense, with my board to pay here, + rent to pay at the other end of the line. We pay $14 a month rent, but we now have the barn rented for $1, so that just now we are paying but $13. Then of course I do not like the idea of being away from home, with all those little children to be cared for.
Zaidee has been for the past month at Eureka, attending the County Institute, with the intention of teaching next winter. She will go to the folks, probably, this coming week.

(5)
Howard has been working on the Evening Journal (The Topeka State Journal) for two weeks. One of the reporters left, and he was given a chance to try his hand. He had sought work there a few weeks before and therefore--crossed out had been told to hand in work on trial whenever he cared to do so, which he had done; so that when the opening came, he already had standing at court. But I do not know whether he will be continued there or not, and, indeed, I fear he will not get much pay for it anyway. He hoped to learn at the end of this past week what he would get, as it was the end of the month. He is quite enthusiastic over it, though I fear that his apprenticeship will have to be rather unrenumerative. Later on, however, if he can stand this unrenumerative period, he might find the--crossed out work in this line very helpful. He was 21 years old last Monday, the 25th

Margaret is now nearly 8 years old. Her birthday is just 7 days after the 4th--the 11th. Roberts carries his 12 years and more with ease, though he is rather small and of frail build. Mary, Howard writes, is "spunky," and indeed she has been fully that for some time. She has not been very well. Her teeth have troubled her,--though I think her stomach and eye teeth are now through.
I am now just three counties west of Kiowa, and in a land of winds. I am 96 miles west and 24 miles north of Kiowa. This section has been prosperous of late years, and people feel contented and independent, and think that this is the best and most desirable part of all the world. But I have seen portions of the globe that I like better. Yet the towns are growing, the farmers are successful and happy. They have plenty of money, send their

(7)
children away to be educated, and occasionally indulge in the luxury of the automobile. Plowing is here sometimes done with a steam engine, twelve rows being--crossed out furrows being cut at once. Wheat is somewhat uncertain but very profitable, and alfalfa certain and more profitable. There are not many people here, less than 3000 in the whole of Meade County,--but those that are here can afford cream in their tea at every meal. As nearly as I can decern, the ladies dress in the newest fashions and all use the most approved forms of slang. Indeed it is worthy of note that many of these people have developed wholesomely and gracefully in these remote parts where society has afforded them so little. I find young men and women of twenty years and over, who were born and reared on large

cattle ranches, cut off from the ordinary forms of social intercourse who have no unpleasant mannerisms, either of speech or deportment. The proprieties and graces of life--crossed out cultivated life are as much theirs as though they had been accustomed to the ordinary advantages that fall to more favored American boys + girls. I suspect with a little careful practice they could courtesy before King Edward with as much ease and naturalness as our Alice herself.
This has been for me a lonesome Sunday afternoon, and this letter has helped make it less so. I hope that you will write often, so that my lonesomeness may sometimes be relieved by your letters to me. Love to all the relatives and much for you.
Your Nephew + Brother
J.E. Everett

Fowler, Kansas, July 26, 1906
My Dear Aunt Mary:--
I will not write you a long letter now, but just a note so that you may have word from me. I received a very nice letter from Cousin Hattie this morning and also one from Cousin John Butler. Hattie had sent him one that I had written her, and that prompted him to write.
I received a letter from Howard today also. He has been working on the Evening Journal, as you know, having begun there on June 18. He had received no pay nor any intimation of what his pay would be, if any, and he seemed to lack courage enough to inquire about it. He writes me that yesterday the 26th Mr. Kiene, his "boss" handed him a check for $13.50 which is his pay up to July 1, and is at

the rate of $30 a month, "which is considerable more, Mr Kiene says, than they ever gave a new man before." For July, he adds, he is to get $35. That is pretty well, I thnk, especially as he hardly had courage enough to begin with, to go and apply for the job, and has been too bashful for six weeks to ask whether his work was going to be rewarded with any pay. But he seems to do all right in his work, for he is getting better assignments than at first.
Out State Superintendent, Dr. Thayer was here yesterday. He is going to help these two fields to employ a pastor for full time, instead of having one pastor supply both. That is what I hope to see done when I leave. An opening will probably be presented for me to look into about Sept 1 to 15.
Did I write you that Zaidee got

(3)
her certificate with a good percentage in her examinations. The last I heard of her--a few days ago--she was down in Greenwood County hunting a school. The Superintendent of public instruction of Ford County writes me that he can probably get a school for her. But I think she will get something in Greenwood County.
I continue to feel well. The weather here, though quite hot a good deal of the time, is not ordinarely oppressive this season. We have a good breeze most of the time, and yet very little of the exceedingly heavy wind that Western Kansas can sometimes provide.
The folks at home are fairly well, Helen writes that Mary has been cross nearly all the time. She says that Margaret is a great deal of help in taking care of Mary. Roberts is not very strong

I hope you have had a pleasant visit with Lewis. He used to be a good boy when we knew him, + I have no doubt is yet. We have not seen him for about four years. Is he still in the East? The Arwenydd? came yesterday. Thank you. Also the Boonville Herald, which I was glad to see.
With much love
Your Nephew, J.E. Everett

Your letter of the 24 is at hand, having come to Fowler first, then to Ford, then back here to Fowler again. I have been somewhat uncertain in my place of habitation since our meetings began. Though this is my Ford Sunday, I am here at Fowler, Mr. Fisher being at Ford. This brother who is holding my Ford meetings is my successor in the third remove in the Kiowa pulpit. The coming week I shall probably be back there a day or two and then be here next Sunday. During the coming week I may be addressed here.
It is quite likely that I shall be in this Western field only about one or two Sundays longer. Since writing ink splotch yesterday, I have heard from Dr. Thayer, our superintendent, that he will probably have either an opening for me to candidate right along, or that he will make arrangements for me to go to Wellington to supply for two or three
